DADOS-GERAIS.NOME-EM-CITACOES-BIBLIOGRAFICAS: LINS, Rafael Dueire;Lins, Rafael Dueire;R. D. Lins;Rafael D. Lins;Rafael Dueire Lins;Rafael Lins;Lins, Rafael D.;Lins, R.;Dueire Lins, Rafael

RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH:
Rafael Dueire Lins é Engenheiro Eletrônico pela Universidade Federal de Pernambuco 1982. Concluiu o Ph.D. in Computing - University of Kent at Canterbury em 1986. Atualmente é Professor Titular da Universidade Federal de Pernambuco. Possui 10 livros publicados, dentre eles o best-seller "Garbage Collection: Algorithms for Dynamic Memory Management", publicado pela John Wiley & Sons em 1996 e traduzido para o chinês em 2004. Dentre as suas contribuições destacam-se a Criação do Lambda-cálculo com Substituições Explicitas, a primeira solução geral e eficiente para o problema de Referências Cíclicas e o pioneirismo em engenharia de documentos e geração de bibliotecas digitais em toda a América Latina, tendo sido o primeiro pesquisador a tratar da interferência frente-verso em documentos. Orientou 48 dissertações de mestrado e 11 teses de doutorado nas áreas de Ciência da Computação e Engenharia Elétrica. Foi professor fundador dos doutorados em Informática (1990) e do Programa de Pós-Graduação em Engenharia Elétrica (2000) ambos dada UFPE onde atua até a presente data. Foi fundador do Programa de Pós-graduação em Computação da Universidade do Minho (1988) em Braga, Portugal. Foi idealizador e coordenador acadêmico (2007/2013) do DINTER entre a UFPE e a UEA (Universidade do Estado do Amazonas) que titulou nove doutores em Engenharia Elétrica. Foi Professor Honorário da University of Kent de 1986 a 1996. Atua na área de Engenharia da Computação e de Telecomunicações.
Informações adicionais e cópias das publicações podem ser obtidas no endereço: https://sites.google.com/site/rafaeldueirelins/
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN:
Rafael Dueire Lins holds a B.Sc. degree in Electrical Engineering (Electronics) from the Federal University of Pernambuco, Brazil (1982) and a Ph.D. degree in Computing from the University of Kent at Canterbury, UK (1986). Lins published 10 books, amongst them the best-seller "Garbage Collection: Algorithms for Dynamic Memory Management", (John Wiley & Sons , UK,1996) translated into Chinese (Mandarin) and published by ChinaPub in 2004. His pioneering contributions encompass the creation of the Lambda-Calculus with explicit substitutions, the first general and efficient solution to cyclic reference counting in sequential, parallel and distributed architectures. Lins is the pioneer researcher in document engineering and digital libraries in Latin America. In this area, he was the first to address the problem of back-to-front interference (bleeding) in documents. Lins supervised in computer science and electrical engineering. Lins is a founding member of the doctoral programme in Computer Science (1990) and in Electrical Engineering (2000) both at Federal University of Pernambuco, Brazil, in which he supervised 48 M.Sc dissertations and 11 Ph.D. theses.
Further information and copies of publications may be found at: https://sites.google.com/site/rafaeldueirelins/

AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: LINS, Rafael Dueire;Lins, Rafael Dueire;R. D. Lins;Rafael D. Lins;Rafael Dueire Lins;Rafael Lins;Lins, Rafael D.;Lins, R.;Dueire Lins, Rafael

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Abstract: BigBatch is an image processing environment designed to process batches of thousands of monochromatic documents. One of the flexibilities and pioneer aspects of BigBatch is offering the possibility of working in distributed environments such as clusters and grids. This paper presents an overview of BigBatch image processing features and analyzes the results of a number of experiments devised to compare its cluster and grid configurations. Although preliminary results were published earlier on, the new data shown here that sheds new lights onto this aspect. The results obtained exhibit almost no difference in total execution times for some grid and cluster configurations, but significant differences for others, indicating that the choice between such configurations must take into account a number of details in order to reach peak performance. Besides those, there are other qualitative aspects that may impact this choice. This paper analyzes these aspects and provides a general picture of how to successfully use BigBatch to process document images employing computers in parallel for this task.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Abstract: BigBatch is an image processing environment designed to process batches of thousands of monochromatic documents. One of the flexibilities and pioneer aspects of BigBatch is offering the possibility of working in distributed environments such as clusters and grids. This paper presents an overview of BigBatch image processing features and analyzes the results of a number of experiments devised to compare its cluster and grid configurations. Although preliminary results were published earlier on, the new data shown here that sheds new lights onto this aspect. The results obtained exhibit almost no difference in total execution times for some grid and cluster configurations, but significant differences for others, indicating that the choice between such configurations must take into account a number of details in order to reach peak performance. Besides those, there are other qualitative aspects that may impact this choice. This paper analyzes these aspects and provides a general picture of how to successfully use BigBatch to process document images employing computers in parallel for this task.

AUTORES.NOME-PARA-CITACAO: Silva, Gabriel de França Pereira e
LINS, Rafael Dueire;Lins, Rafael Dueire;R. D. Lins;Rafael D. Lins;Rafael Dueire Lins;Rafael Lins;Lins, Rafael D.;Lins, R.;Dueire Lins, Rafael

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: Abstract: Portable digital cameras are being used widely by students and professionals in different fields as a practical way to digitize documents. Tools such as PhotoDoc enable the batch processing of such documents, performing automatic border removal and perspective correction. A PhotoDoc processed document and a scanned one look very similar to the human eye if both are in true color. However, if one tries to automatically binarize a batch of documents digitized from portable cameras compared to scanners, they have different features. The knowledge of their source is fundamental for successful processing. This paper presents a classification strategy to distinguish between scanned and photographed documents. Over 16,000 documents were tested with a correct classification rate of over 99.96%.
INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS-INGLES: Abstract: Portable digital cameras are being used widely by students and professionals in different fields as a practical way to digitize documents. Tools such as PhotoDoc enable the batch processing of such documents, performing automatic border removal and perspective correction. A PhotoDoc processed document and a scanned one look very similar to the human eye if both are in true color. The knowledge of their source is fundamental for successful processing. This paper presents a classification strategy to distinguish between scanned and photographed documents. Over 16,000 documents were tested with a correct classification rate of over 99.96%.
